1.text: My son, pay attention to my wisdom; incline your ear to my insight,

2.text: that you may maintain discretion and your lips may preserve knowledge.

3.text: Though the lips of the forbidden woman drip honey and her speech is smoother than oil,

4.text: in the end she is bitter as wormwood, sharp as a double-edged sword.

5.text: Her feet go down to death; her steps lead straight to Sheol.

6.text: She does not consider the path of life; she does not know that her ways are unstable.

7.text: So now, my sons, listen to me, and do not turn aside from the words of my mouth.

8.text: Keep your path far from her; do not go near the door of her house,

9.text: lest you concede your vigor to others, and your years to one who is cruel;

10.text: lest strangers feast on your wealth, and your labors enrich the house of a foreigner.

11.text: At the end of your life you will groan when your flesh and your body are spent,

12.text: and you will say, “How I hated discipline, and my heart despised reproof!

13.text: I did not listen to the voice of my teachers or incline my ear to my mentors.

14.text: I am on the brink of utter ruin in the midst of the whole assembly.”

15.text: Drink water from your own cistern, and running water from your own well.

16.text: Why should your springs flow in the streets, your streams of water in the public squares?

17.text: Let them be yours alone, never to be shared with strangers.

18.text: May your fountain be blessed, and may you rejoice in the wife of your youth:

19.text: A loving doe, a graceful fawn—may her breasts satisfy you always; may you be captivated by her love forever.

20.text: Why be captivated, my son, by an adulteress, or embrace the bosom of a stranger?

21.text: For a man’s ways are before the eyes of the LORD, and the LORD examines all his paths.

22.text: The iniquities of a wicked man entrap him; the cords of his sin entangle him.

23.text: He dies for lack of discipline, led astray by his own great folly.
